There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Device Driver Discovery. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Device Driver Discovery
Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to enumerate local device drivers on a victim host. Information about device drivers may highlight various insights that shape follow-on behaviors, such as the function/purpose of the host, present security tools (i.e. [Security Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518/001)) or other defenses (e.g., [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497)), as well as potential exploitable vulnerabilities (e.g., [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068)).

Many OS utilities may provide information about local device drivers, such as `driverquery.exe` and the `EnumDeviceDrivers()` API function on Windows.(Citation: Microsoft Driverquery)(Citation: Microsoft EnumDeviceDrivers) Information about device drivers (as well as associated services, i.e., [System Service Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1007)) may also be available in the Registry.(Citation: Microsoft Registry Drivers)

On Linux/macOS, device drivers (in the form of kernel modules) may be visible within `/dev` or using utilities such as `lsmod` and `modinfo`.(Citation: Linux Kernel Programming)(Citation: lsmod man)(Citation: modinfo man)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

entities.name: DEVICE DRIVER DISCOVERY
entities.description: Device Driver Discovery is an attack technique where adversaries enumerate local device drivers on a victim host to gather insights about the system and potential vulnerabilities.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: SECURITY SOFTWARE DISCOVERY
entities.description: Security Software Discovery is an attack technique that may be related to Device Driver Discovery, as it involves identifying security tools present on a victim host.

entities.name: VIRTUALIZATION/SANDBOX EVASION
entities.description: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion is an attack technique that may be relevant to the context of Device Driver Discovery, as it involves evading detection by security measures.

entities.name: EXPLOITATION FOR PRIVILEGE ESCALATION
entities.description: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation is an attack technique that may be targeted after gathering information through Device Driver Discovery.

entities.name: DRIVERQUERY.EXE
entities.description: Driverquery.exe is a Windows utility that provides information about local device drivers, which can be used in the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: ENUMDEVICEDRIVERS()
entities.description: EnumDeviceDrivers() is a Windows API function that can be utilized to enumerate device drivers on a victim host during the Device Driver Discovery process.

entities.name: REGISTRY
entities.description: The Registry in Windows may contain information about device drivers and associated services, relevant to the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: LSMOD
entities.description: lsmod is a Linux utility that displays information about loaded kernel modules, which can be used in the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: MODINFO
entities.description: modinfo is a Linux utility that provides detailed information about a specific kernel module, relevant to the Device Driver Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: DEV
entities.description: The /dev directory in Linux/macOS contains device files that may be relevant for identifying device drivers during the Device Driver Discovery process.

chunk:
There are 5 software using the attack technique called External Remote Services. Their names are as follows:
* Linux Rabbit
* Mafalda
* Hildegard
* Kinsing
* Doki

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Linux Rabbit
Software description: [Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) is malware that targeted Linux servers and IoT devices in a campaign lasting from August to October 2018. It shares code with another strain of malware known as Rabbot. The goal of the campaign was to install cryptocurrency miners onto the targeted servers and devices.(Citation: Anomali Linux Rabbit 2018)

Platforms: Linux

Software name: Mafalda
Software description: [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) is a flexible interactive implant that has been used by [Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013). Security researchers assess the [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) name may be inspired by an Argentinian cartoon character that has been popular as a means of political commentary since the 1960s. (Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Sept 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Hildegard
Software description: [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations. The malware was first observed in January 2021. The TeamTNT activity group is believed to be behind [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601). (Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Linux, Containers, IaaS

Software name: Kinsing
Software description: [Kinsing](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0599) is Golang-based malware that runs a cryptocurrency miner and attempts to spread itself to other hosts in the victim environment. (Citation: Aqua Kinsing April 2020)(Citation: Sysdig Kinsing November 2020)(Citation: Aqua Security Cloud Native Threat Report June 2021)
Platforms: Containers, Linux

Software name: Doki
Software description: [Doki](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0600) is a backdoor that uses a unique Dogecoin-based Domain Generation Algorithm and was first observed in July 2020. [Doki](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0600) was used in conjunction with the [ngrok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0508) Mining Botnet in a campaign that targeted Docker servers in cloud platforms. (Citation: Intezer Doki July 20)
Platforms: Linux, Containers

entities.description: Linux Rabbit is malware that targeted Linux servers and IoT devices in a campaign lasting from August to October 2018, aiming to install cryptocurrency miners onto the targeted servers and devices.

entities.name: MAFALDA
entities.description: Mafalda is a flexible interactive implant used by the Metador group, possibly inspired by an Argentinian cartoon character known for political commentary.

entities.name: HILDEGARD
entities.description: Hildegard is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations, believed to be associated with the TeamTNT activity group.

entities.name: KINSING
entities.description: Kinsing is Golang-based malware that runs a cryptocurrency miner and attempts to spread itself to other hosts in the victim environment.

entities.name: DOKI
entities.description: Doki is a backdoor that uses a unique Dogecoin-based Domain Generation Algorithm and was first observed in July 2020, used in conjunction with the ngrok Mining Botnet targeting Docker servers in cloud platforms.

entities.name: TEAMTNT
entities.description: TeamTNT is an activity group believed to be behind the Hildegard malware, focusing on cryptocurrency mining and cloud environments.

entities.name: NGROK
entities.description: Ngrok is a tool used in conjunction with the Doki backdoor for mining operations targeting Docker servers.

<data key="d2">4d143f612013d84c16b7e40a63221ad8</data>    </node>    <node id="DOKI">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Doki is a backdoor that uses a unique Dogecoin-based Domain Generation Algorithm and was first observed in July 2020, used in conjunction with the ngrok Mining Botnet targeting Docker servers in cloud platforms.</data>      <data key="d2">4d143f612013d84c16b7e40a63221ad8</data>    </node>    <node id="TEAMTNT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">TeamTNT is an activity group believed to be behind the chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Create or Modify System Process. Their names are as follows:
* Exaramel for Linux
* LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Exaramel for Linux
Software description: [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) is a backdoor written in the Go Programming Language and compiled as a 64-bit ELF binary. The Windows version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA
Software description: [LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1121) is a backdoor that was used by UNC5325 during [Cutting Edge](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0029) to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and to establish persistence across system upgrades and patches.(Citation: Mandiant Cutting Edge Part 3 February 2024)
Platforms: Network

entities.name: EXARAMEL FOR LINUX
entities.description: Exaramel for Linux is a backdoor software written in the Go Programming Language, compiled as a 64-bit ELF binary, and operates on the Linux platform.

entities.name: LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA
entities.description: LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA is a backdoor software used by UNC5325 to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and establish persistence across system upgrades and patches.

entities.name: UNC5325
entities.description: UNC5325 is a threat actor group that utilized LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA during the Cutting Edge campaign.

entities.name: CUTTING EDGE
entities.description: Cutting Edge is a campaign during which LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA was used to deploy malware on targeted systems.

entities.name: ESET TELEBOTS
entities.description: ESET TeleBots is a cybersecurity firm that provided information about Exaramel for Linux in October 2018.

entities.name: IVANTI CONNECT SECURE
entities.description: Ivanti Connect Secure is a VPN solution targeted by LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA for malware deployment.

chunk: There are 8 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called OS Credential Dumping. Their names are as follows: * Security Account Manager * LSA Secrets * DCSync * Proc Filesystem * NTDS * Cached Domain Credentials * LSASS Memory * /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: OS Credential Dumping Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password. Credentials can be obtained from OS caches, memory, or structures.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) Credentials can then be used to perform [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) and access restricted information. Several of the tools mentioned in associated sub-techniques may be used by both adversaries and professional security testers. Additional custom tools likely exist as well. Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS Attack technique name: Security Account Manager Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to extract credential material from the Security Account Manager (SAM) database either through in-memory techniques or through the Windows Registry where the SAM database is stored. The SAM is a database file that contains local accounts for the host, typically those found with the net user command. Enumerating the SAM database requires SYSTEM level access. A number of tools can be used to retrieve the SAM file through in-memory techniques: * pwdumpx.exe * [gsecdump](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0008) * [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) * secretsdump.py Alternatively, the SAM can be extracted from the Registry with Reg: * reg save HKLM\sam sam * reg save HKLM\system system Creddump7 can then be used to process the SAM database locally to retrieve hashes.(Citation: GitHub Creddump7) Notes: * RID 500 account is the local, built-in administrator. * RID 501 is the guest account. * User accounts start with a RID of 1,000+. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: LSA Secrets Attack technique description: Adversaries with SYSTEM access to a host may attempt to access Local Security Authority (LSA) secrets, which can contain a variety of different credential materials, such as credentials for service accounts.(Citation: Passcape LSA Secrets)(Citation: Microsoft AD Admin Tier Model)(Citation: Tilbury Windows Credentials) LSA secrets are stored in the registry at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SECURITY\Policy\Secrets. LSA secrets can also be dumped from memory.(Citation: ired Dumping LSA Secrets) [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) can be used to extract from the Registry. [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) can be used to extract secrets from memory.(Citation: ired Dumping LSA Secrets) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: DCSync Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access credentials and other sensitive information by abusing a Windows Domain Controller's application programming interface (API)(Citation: Microsoft DRSR Dec 2017) (Citation: Microsoft GetNCCChanges) (Citation: Samba DRSUAPI) (Citation: Wine API samlib.dll) to simulate the replication process from a remote domain controller using a technique called DCSync. Members of the Administrators, Domain Admins, and Enterprise Admin groups or computer accounts on the domain controller are able to run DCSync to pull password data(Citation: ADSecurity Mimikatz DCSync) from Active Directory, which may include current and historical hashes of potentially useful accounts such as KRBTGT and Administrators. The hashes can then in turn be used to create a [Golden Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1558/001) for use in [Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/003)(Citation: Harmj0y Mimikatz and DCSync) or change an account's password as noted in [Account Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1098).(Citation: InsiderThreat ChangeNTLM July 2017) DCSync functionality has been included in the "lsadump" module in [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: GitHub Mimikatz lsadump Module) Lsadump also includes NetSync, which performs DCSync over a legacy replication protocol.(Citation: Microsoft NRPC Dec 2017) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Proc Filesystem Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather credentials from the proc filesystem or `/proc`. The proc filesystem is a pseudo-filesystem used as an interface to kernel data structures for Linux based systems managing virtual memory. For each process, the `/proc//maps` file shows how memory is mapped within the process’s virtual address space. And `/proc//mem`, exposed for debugging purposes, provides access to the process’s virtual address space.(Citation: Picus Labs Proc cump 2022)(Citation: baeldung Linux proc map 2022) When executing with root privileges, adversaries can search these memory locations for all

entities.name: OS CREDENTIAL DUMPING
entities.description: OS Credential Dumping is an attack technique where adversaries attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, typically in the form of a hash or clear text password, from various sources within an operating system.

entities.name: SECURITY ACCOUNT MANAGER
entities.description: Security Account Manager is a database that contains local accounts for the host, and adversaries may extract credential material from it through in-memory techniques or the Windows Registry.

entities.name: LSA SECRETS
entities.description: LSA Secrets are credential materials stored in the Local Security Authority, which can be accessed by adversaries with SYSTEM access, and are stored in the registry or can be dumped from memory.

entities.name: DCSYNC
entities.description: DCSync is an attack technique where adversaries simulate the replication process from a remote domain controller to access credentials and sensitive information from Active Directory.

entities.name: PROC FILESYSTEM
entities.description: Proc Filesystem is a pseudo-filesystem in Linux that provides an interface to kernel data structures, allowing adversaries to gather credentials from memory locations of processes.

entities.name: NTDS
entities.description: NTDS refers to the Active Directory database that stores user account information and credentials, which can be targeted by various credential dumping techniques.

entities.name: CACHED DOMAIN CREDENTIALS
entities.description: Cached Domain Credentials are stored credentials that allow users to log in to a domain without needing to contact a domain controller, and can be targeted by adversaries.

entities.name: LSASS MEMORY
entities.description: LSASS Memory refers to the memory space of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service, which can contain sensitive credential information and is a target for credential dumping.

entities.name: /ETC/PASSWD AND /ETC/SHADOW
entities.description: These are files in Unix/Linux systems that store user account information and password hashes, which can be exploited by adversaries to gain unauthorized access.

entities.name: ADVERSARIES
entities.description: Adversaries are individuals or groups that attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in systems to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information.

entities.name: PROFESSIONAL SECURITY TESTERS
entities.description: Professional security testers are individuals who assess the security of systems and networks, often using similar techniques as adversaries to identify vulnerabilities.

chunk: kernel data structures for Linux based systems managing virtual memory. For each process, the `/proc//maps` file shows how memory is mapped within the process’s virtual address space. And `/proc//mem`, exposed for debugging purposes, provides access to the process’s virtual address space.(Citation: Picus Labs Proc cump 2022)(Citation: baeldung Linux proc map 2022) When executing with root privileges, adversaries can search these memory locations for all processes on a system that contain patterns indicative of credentials. Adversaries may use regex patterns, such as grep -E "^[0-9a-f-]* r" /proc/"$pid"/maps | cut -d' ' -f 1, to look for fixed strings in memory structures or cached hashes.(Citation: atomic-red proc file system) When running without privileged access, processes can still view their own virtual memory locations. Some services or programs may save credentials in clear text inside the process’s memory.(Citation: MimiPenguin GitHub May 2017)(Citation: Polop Linux PrivEsc Gitbook) If running as or with the permissions of a web browser, a process can search the `/maps` & `/mem` locations for common website credential patterns (that can also be used to find adjacent memory within the same structure) in which hashes or cleartext credentials may be located. Platforms: Linux Attack technique name: NTDS Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information, as well as obtain other information about domain members such as devices, users, and access rights. By default, the NTDS file (NTDS.dit) is located in %SystemRoot%\NTDS\Ntds.dit of a domain controller.(Citation: Wikipedia Active Directory) In addition to looking for NTDS files on active Domain Controllers, adversaries may search for backups that contain the same or similar information.(Citation: Metcalf 2015) The following tools and techniques can be used to enumerate the NTDS file and the contents of the entire Active Directory hashes. * Volume Shadow Copy * secretsdump.py * Using the in-built Windows tool, ntdsutil.exe * Invoke-NinjaCopy Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Cached Domain Credentials Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access cached domain credentials used to allow authentication to occur in the event a domain controller is unavailable.(Citation: Microsoft - Cached Creds) On Windows Vista and newer, the hash format is DCC2 (Domain Cached Credentials version 2) hash, also known as MS-Cache v2 hash.(Citation: PassLib mscache) The number of default cached credentials varies and can be altered per system. This hash does not allow pass-the-hash style attacks, and instead requires [Password Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to recover the plaintext password.(Citation: ired mscache) On Linux systems, Active Directory credentials can be accessed through caches maintained by software like System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) or Quest Authentication Services (formerly VAS). Cached credential hashes are typically located at `/var/lib/sss/db/cache.[domain].ldb` for SSSD or `/var/opt/quest/vas/authcache/vas_auth.vdb` for Quest. Adversaries can use utilities, such as `tdbdump`, on these database files to dump the cached hashes and use [Password Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to obtain the plaintext password.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) With SYSTEM or sudo access, the tools/utilities such as [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075), and secretsdump.py for Windows or Linikatz for Linux can be used to extract the cached credentials.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) Note: Cached credentials for Windows Vista are derived using PBKDF2.(Citation: PassLib mscache) Platforms: Windows, Linux Attack technique name: LSASS Memory Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that is widely used for various applications, including server management and software development.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a series of operating systems developed by Microsoft, commonly used for personal computers and enterprise environments.

entities.name: NTDS
entities.description: NTDS refers to the Active Directory domain database file that stores information about domain members, including users and devices.

entities.name: LSASS
entities.description: LSASS (Local Security Authority Subsystem Service) is a process in Windows that is responsible for enforcing the security policy on the system and managing user logins.

entities.name: CACHED DOMAIN CREDENTIALS
entities.description: Cached Domain Credentials are stored credentials that allow authentication when a domain controller is unavailable, particularly in Windows environments.

entities.name: MIMIKATZ
entities.description: Mimikatz is a tool used to extract plaintext passwords, hashes, PIN codes, and Kerberos tickets from memory.

entities.name: PROCDUMP
entities.description: Procdump is a command-line utility for Windows that allows users to create memory dumps of processes.

entities.name: SECRETSDUMP.PY
entities.description: Secretsdump.py is a tool used to extract credentials from Windows systems, particularly from the NTDS file.

entities.name: BAELDUNG
entities.description: Baeldung is a website that offers tutorials and articles on various programming topics, including Linux and system administration.

entities.name: ATOMIC RED
entities.description: Atomic Red is a cybersecurity organization that provides resources and tools for understanding and mitigating threats in computer systems.

entities.name: MIMIPENGUIN
entities.description: MimiPenguin is a GitHub repository that shares tools and techniques for security research, particularly in the context of Linux systems.

entities.name: POLLOP
entities.description: Polop is a cybersecurity organization that focuses on privilege escalation techniques and security best practices in Linux environments.

entities.name: METCALF
entities.description: Metcalf is an author who has contributed to literature on cybersecurity, particularly regarding Active Directory and credential management.

entities.name: BRINING
entities.description: Brining is a researcher known for contributions to cybersecurity, particularly in the context of tools like Mimikatz and credential extraction techniques.

chunk: -in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to dump the contents of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to enable offline password cracking. Most modern Linux operating systems use a combination of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow to store user account information including password hashes in /etc/shadow. By default, /etc/shadow is only readable by the root user.(Citation: Linux Password and Shadow File Formats) The Linux utility, unshadow, can be used to combine the two files in a format suited for password cracking utilities such as John the Ripper:(Citation: nixCraft - John the Ripper) # /usr/bin/unshadow /etc/passwd /etc/shadow > /tmp/crack.password.db Platforms: Linux

entities.name: COMSVCS.DLL
entities.description: comsvcs.dll is a Windows tool used for creating memory dumps and managing services in the Windows operating system.

entities.name: LSASS.EXE
entities.description: lsass.exe is a process in Windows that handles security policies and user authentication.

entities.description: WerFault.exe is a Windows Error Reporting tool that can be exploited to create memory dumps.

entities.name: MSV
entities.description: Msv is an authentication package used for interactive, batch, and service logons in Windows.

entities.name: WDIGEST
entities.description: Wdigest is a protocol for Digest Authentication used in HTTP and SASL exchanges.

entities.name: KERBEROS
entities.description: Kerberos is a network authentication protocol designed for mutual authentication in Windows environments.

entities.name: CREDSSP
entities.description: CredSSP is a security support provider that enables single sign-on and network-level authentication for Remote Desktop Services.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that uses a combination of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow for user account information.

entities.name: UNSHADOW
entities.description: Unshadow is a Linux utility used to combine /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files for password cracking.

entities.name: JOHN THE RIPPER
entities.description: John the Ripper is a popular password cracking utility that can be used to crack password hashes.

entities.name: ETC/PASSWD
entities.description: The /etc/passwd file is a standard file in Unix-like operating systems that stores user account information.

entities.name: ETC/SHADOW
entities.description: The /etc/shadow file is used in Unix-like operating systems to store password hashes and related information securely.

* Network Intrusion Prevention

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering, configuring software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: NETWORK APPLIANCES
entities.description: Network appliances are hardware devices used to manage and filter network traffic, playing a crucial role in the mitigation of attacks.

entities.name: INTRUSION DETECTION SIGNATURES
entities.description: Intrusion detection signatures are predefined patterns used to identify and block malicious traffic at network boundaries.

Software name: HOPLIGHT
Software description: [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) is a backdoor Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government.(Citation: US-CERT HOPLIGHT Apr 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remsec
Software description: [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is a modular backdoor that has been used by [Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) and appears to have been designed primarily for espionage purposes. Many of its modules are written in Lua. (Citation: Symantec Strider Blog)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 
* Filter Network Traffic 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols to intercept and manipulate network traffic.

entities.name: SMB RELAY
entities.description: SMB Relay is an attack technique that allows an attacker to intercept and relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: A mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: A mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: A mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: A mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to enhance security.

entities.name: NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Network traffic refers to the data that is transmitted over a network, which can be subject to various attack techniques like LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay.

intercept and relay authentication requests to gain unauthorized access to network resources.</data>      <data key="d2">38cc990d0bb9edafa8f1949b602d3a2e</data>    </node>    <node id="DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">A mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.</data>      <data key="d2">38cc990d0bb9edafa8f1949b602d3a2e</data>    </node>    <node id="NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">A mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries to prevent unauthorized access.</data>      <data key="d2">38cc990d0bb9edafa8f1949b602d3a2e</data>    </node>    <node id="NETWORK SEGMENTATION">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">A mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.</data>      <data key="d2">38cc990d0bb9edafa8f1949b602d3a2e</data>    </node>    <node id="FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">A mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering to enhance security.</data>      <data key="d2">38cc990d0bb9edafa8f1949b602d3a2e</data>    </node>    <node id="NETWORK TRAFFIC">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Network chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called System Owner/User Discovery. Their names are as follows:
* NBTscan
* Koadic
* Pupy
* AsyncRAT
* QuasarRAT
* BloodHound
* SILENTTRINITY
* Empire
* Trojan.Karagany
* PoetRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: NBTscan
Software description: [NBTscan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0590) is an open source tool that has been used by state groups to conduct internal reconnaissance within a compromised network.(Citation: Debian nbtscan Nov 2019)(Citation: SecTools nbtscan June 2003)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)(Citation: FireEye APT39 Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BloodHound
Software description: [BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) is an Active Directory (AD) reconnaissance tool that can reveal hidden relationships and identify attack paths within an AD environment.(Citation: GitHub Bloodhound)(Citation: CrowdStrike BloodHound April 2018)(Citation: FoxIT Wocao December 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Trojan.Karagany
Software description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Drag

/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PoetRAT
Software description: [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that was first identified in April 2020. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has been used in multiple campaigns against the private and public sectors in Azerbaijan, including ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector. The STIBNITE activity group has been observed using the malware. [PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) derived its name from references in the code to poet William Shakespeare. (Citation: Talos PoetRAT April 2020)(Citation: Talos PoetRAT October 2020)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: DRAGONFLY
entities.description: Dragonfly is a cyber threat group linked to various malware attacks, including the use of remote access tools for reconnaissance purposes.

entities.name: TROJAN.KARAGANY
entities.description: Trojan.Karagany is a remote access trojan that originated from Dream Loader malware and is associated with cyber espionage activities.

entities.name: DREAM LOADER
entities.description: Dream Loader is a type of malware that was leaked in 2010 and has been sold on underground forums, serving as a source for other malware like Trojan.Karagany.

entities.name: POETRAT
entities.description: PoetRAT is a remote access trojan first identified in April 2020, used in campaigns against sectors in Azerbaijan, particularly targeting ICS and SCADA systems in the energy sector.

entities.name: STIBNITE
entities.description: STIBNITE is an activity group observed using PoetRAT in various cyber campaigns.

entities.name: AZERBAIJAN
entities.description: Azerbaijan is a country that has been targeted by cyber campaigns utilizing PoetRAT against its private and public sectors.

entities.name: SYMANTEC
entities.description: Symantec is a cybersecurity company known for its antivirus products and threat intelligence, mentioned in connection with Dragonfly.

entities.name: DRAGOS
entities.description: Dragos is a cybersecurity firm specializing in industrial control systems security, referenced in the context of both PoetRAT and Trojan.Karagany.

entities.name: ICS
entities.description: ICS (Industrial Control Systems) refers to systems used to control industrial processes, which have been targeted by cyber campaigns involving PoetRAT.

entities.name: SCADA
entities.description: SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) systems are used for industrial control and have been targeted in cyber campaigns against Azerbaijan.)<|COMPLETE|>

<data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Dream Loader is a type of malware that was leaked in 2010 and has been sold on underground forums, serving as a source for other malware like There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Sharepoint. Their names are as follows:
* Audit 
* User Account Management 
* User Training 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at training users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce risks associated with spearphishing and social engineering.

chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Cloud Instance Metadata API. Their names are as follows:
* Peirates
* Hildegard

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Peirates
Software description: [Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework with a focus on gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation. The tool is written in GoLang and publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: Peirates GitHub)
Platforms: Containers

Software name: Hildegard
Software description: [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations. The malware was first observed in January 2021. The TeamTNT activity group is believed to be behind [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601). (Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Linux, Containers, IaaS

entities.description: Peirates is a post-exploitation Kubernetes exploitation framework designed for gathering service account tokens for lateral movement and privilege escalation, written in GoLang and available on GitHub.

entities.description: Hildegard is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations, first observed in January 2021 and attributed to the TeamTNT activity group.

entities.description: TeamTNT is a cybercriminal group known for its activities involving cryptocurrency mining and targeting cloud environments, particularly Kubernetes.

on GitHub.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="HILDEGARD">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Hildegard is malware that targets misconfigured kubelets for initial access and runs cryptocurrency miner operations, first observed in January 2021 and attributed to the TeamTNT activity group.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="TEAMTNT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">TeamTNT is a cybercriminal group known for its activities involving cryptocurrency mining and targeting cloud environments, particularly Kubernetes.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="GO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Go is a programming language developed by Google, known for its simplicity and efficiency, often used in cloud and server-side applications.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="LINUX">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">Linux is a family of open-source Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel, widely used in server environments and cloud computing.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="IAAS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) is a form of cloud computing that provides virtualized computing resources over the internet, allowing users to manage and control their infrastructure.</data>      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <node id="KUBERNETES">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </node>    <edge source="PEIRATES" target="HILDEGARD">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both Peirates and Hildegard are software tools related to Kubernetes exploitation and security vulnerabilities in cloud environments.</data>      <data key="d5">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PEIRATES" target="GO">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Peirates is written in Go, indicating a relationship between the software and the programming language used for its development.</data>      <data key="d5">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PEIRATES" target="KUBERNETES">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">Peirates is a Kubernetes exploitation framework, directly linking it to the Kubernetes platform it is designed to target.</data>      <data key="d5">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </edge>    <edge source="HILDEGARD" target="TEAMTNT">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Hildegard is attributed to the TeamTNT activity group, which is known for its malicious activities in cloud environments.</data>      <data key="d5">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </edge>    <edge source="HILDEGARD" target="LINUX">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Hildegard operates on Linux platforms, establishing a direct relationship between the malware and the operating system it targets.</data>      <data key="d5">8717a33221120fff5637cbfd7c539800</data>    </edge>    <edge source="HILDEGARD" target="IAAS">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Hildegard is used in IaaS environments, indicating its relevance in cloud computing and infrastructure chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Service Stop. Their names are as follows:
* Network Segmentation 
* User Account Management 
* Restrict Registry Permissions 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves restricting access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: SERVICE STOP
entities.description: Service Stop is an attack technique that targets services running on a system, aiming to disrupt their normal operation and availability.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 9 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Create or Modify System Process. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Limit Software Installation 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Audit 
* Software Configuration 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Code Signing 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software to maintain system integrity.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root accounts.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to harden the system against various attack techniques.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements changes to software configurations to mitigate security risks associated with how the software operates.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that sets directory and file permissions to restrict access, enhancing security.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity through digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: CREATE OR MODIFY SYSTEM PROCESS
entities.description: Create or Modify System Process is an attack technique that involves unauthorized changes to system processes, which can compromise system integrity.

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Security Support Provider. Their names are as follows:
* Mimikatz
* Empire
* PowerSploit

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Net Crawler
Software description: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: Password Cracking is an attack technique used by software like Net Crawler to gain unauthorized access to systems by recovering passwords.

chunk:
There are 2 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Data from Configuration Repository. Their names are as follows:
* Network Device Configuration Dump
* SNMP (MIB Dump)

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Data from Configuration Repository
Attack technique description: Adversaries may collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories. Configuration repositories are used by management systems in order to configure, manage, and control data on remote systems. Configuration repositories may also facilitate remote access and administration of devices.

Adversaries may target these repositories in order to collect large quantities of sensitive system administration data. Data from configuration repositories may be exposed by various protocols and software and can store a wide variety of data, much of which may align with adversary Discovery objectives.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: US-CERT TA17-156A SNMP Abuse 2017)
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: Network Device Configuration Dump
Attack technique description: Adversaries may access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network. The network configuration is a file containing parameters that determine the operation of the device. The device typically stores an in-memory copy of the configuration while operating, and a separate configuration on non-volatile storage to load after device reset. Adversaries can inspect the configuration files to reveal information about the target network and its layout, the network device and its software, or identifying legitimate accounts and credentials for later use.

Adversaries can use common management tools and protocols, such as Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) and Smart Install (SMI), to access network configuration files.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) These tools may be used to query specific data from a configuration repository or configure the device to export the configuration for later analysis. 
Platforms: Network

Attack technique name: SNMP (MIB Dump)
Attack technique description: Adversaries may target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect and/or mine valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

The MIB is a configuration repository that stores variable information accessible via SNMP in the form of object identifiers (OID). Each OID identifies a variable that can be read or set and permits active management tasks, such as configuration changes, through remote modification of these variables. SNMP can give administrators great insight in their systems, such as, system information, description of hardware, physical location, and software packages(Citation: SANS Information Security Reading Room Securing SNMP Securing SNMP). The MIB may also contain device operational information, including running configuration, routing table, and interface details.

Adversaries may use SNMP queries to collect MIB content directly from SNMP-managed devices in order to collect network information that allows the adversary to build network maps and facilitate future targeted exploitation.(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks) 
Platforms: Network

entities.name: DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY
entities.description: Data from Configuration Repository is an attack technique where adversaries collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories used by management systems to configure and control remote systems.

entities.name: NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP
entities.description: Network Device Configuration Dump is an attack technique where adversaries access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network.

entities.name: SNMP (MIB DUMP)
entities.description: SNMP (MIB Dump) is an attack technique where adversaries target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

entities.name: SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)
entities.description: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a protocol used for network management, allowing administrators to manage devices on IP networks.

entities.name: MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)
entities.description: The Management Information Base (MIB) is a database used for managing the entities in a communication network, containing variable information accessible via SNMP.

the network.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">SNMP (MIB Dump) is an attack technique where adversaries target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a protocol used for network management, allowing administrators to manage devices on IP networks.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">The Management Information Base (MIB) is a database used for managing the entities in a communication network, containing variable information accessible via SNMP.</data>      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <node id="CONFIGURATION REPOSITORIES">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </node>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques involve adversaries collecting sensitive data from network configurations and repositories</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques involve adversaries targeting repositories to extract sensitive information</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DATA FROM CONFIGURATION REPOSITORY" target="CONFIGURATION REPOSITORIES">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Configuration repositories are the source from which data is collected in the Data from Configuration Repository attack technique</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="NETWORK DEVICE CONFIGURATION DUMP" target="SNMP (MIB DUMP)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques utilize network management protocols to access sensitive data</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SNMP (MIB DUMP)" target="SIMPLE NETWORK MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL (SNMP)">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">SNMP is the protocol used to access the Management Information Base (MIB) for collecting valuable network information</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SNMP (MIB DUMP)" target="MANAGEMENT INFORMATION BASE (MIB)">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The MIB is the repository accessed by SNMP to gather information about network devices</data>      <data key="d5">03a781941d71a6329ebacaaec35bab9c</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Proc Filesystem. Their names are as follows:
* LaZagne
* MimiPenguin
* PACEMAKER

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: MimiPenguin
Software description: [MimiPenguin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0179) is a credential dumper, similar to [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002), designed specifically for Linux platforms. (Citation: MimiPenguin GitHub May 2017)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: PACEMAKER
Software description: [PACEMAKER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1109) is a credential stealer that was used by [APT5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1023) as early as 2020 including activity against US Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies.(Citation: Mandiant Pulse Secure Zero-Day April 2021)
Platforms: Network, Linux

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Winlogon Helper DLL. Their names are as follows:
* Execution Prevention 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.
